Description: Body sherd of North Ionian black-figured pottery dinos; exterior: dull cream slip: from top, black band; black-figure decoration consisting of procession of deer running left, with incised and white-dotted dappling (at left, rump and hind legs of one deer, followed by a fully preserved second; to right, only antlers, snout and forelegs of third deer); below black band and reserved area.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.54b.1899, GR.54c.1899, GR.54d.1899, GR.54e.1899, GR.54f.1899, and Cairo JE46338. Cook suggests that this sherd belongs to an early and experimental phase of the Clazomenian black-figure style. E.R. Price (East Greek Pottery, 1927, 22) argued that white-slip Clazomenian pottery was the link between the Clazomenian sarcophagi, which were covered in a white slip, and the later Clazomenian black-figure wares. She explained that the features (the use of white dots as well as the use of white lines together with incised lines for inner details) on the white slip sherds are paralleled both on the sarcophagi and the later vases. Cook (1952 note 64) rejected that argument on the basis of both dating and styles.
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 138-9, no. Ia)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 38, no. 1, pl. XIX, no. 1)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 59, pl. VI, no. 9b)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 254, no. I (a))
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GI.012) (phase 3)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p.81, Nau 17, pl. 4c-d)
